questions.question_text: Which feature allows reachability to an organization's internally hosted applications for an active DNS security policy on a device?

discussion.content: B is correct, check Page 377 on the official Cisco press book.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct. "If the DNS query is for a local domain, it forwards the query without changing the DNS packet to the DNS server in the enterprise network" ----> https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/security/ios-xe-16/security-book-xe/umbrella-integration.html
it is local domain bypass

I think answer B too.
Link: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/security/vedge-20-x/security-book/cisco-umbrella-integration.html
answer is c

Selected Answer: B
question says, which order. Like for prefix list, acl, in your control policy, data policy etc, always your specifics match must be on the lower sequences, you have to go to specific till general ones, if not the specific ones will never match.
In the same way, if you want to match first prefix list, so you use lower seq for this, next for tloc and so on. I hope it helps.

Selected Answer: C
I am confused, because the question says "Prefer", and preference set is the highest to lowest, which would make C correct
it is B. central control policy: sequence of match-action pairs that are evaulated from lower to higher seq number

How can they both be correct? There is no mention of the word "order" in those options. Both B and C refer to sequence number. B says lowest to highest, and C says the reverse. Only one can be correct.

B. lowest order to highest sequence number
C. highest order to lowest sequence number

Are both B and C correct ??

questions.question_text:
A network administrator is configuring a centralized control policy based on match action pairs for multiple conditions. Which order must be configured to prefer
Prefix List over TLOC and TLOC over Origin?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The network administrator has configured a centralized topology policy that results in the displayed routing table at a branch office. Which two configurations are verified by the output? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: since AD is 251 (default for cisco sd wan router) and route is M (leraned via OMP) B and D should be correct

comments.content: You may be right, but be aware that Cisco is planning to deprecate the "vpn" syntax and use "vrf" for all models.

discussion.content: Correct answers are B and D. B because it uses "vrf" and not "vpn". D because is a "m" route and the AD is 251.
B and D!

Selected Answer: BD
show ip route vrf, so Cedge. Then you can see m for your default route, so you are learning it through OMP , who is anouncing it is system ip 10.1.9.2 and 10.1.9.3 , system ips of the remote site announcing df GW.

Originally OMP has 250 AD value in vEdge platforms. For cEdge it is 251, because NHRP has 250 AD which exists in Cisco OS before SD-WAN.
m* shows routes learned from OMP

Selected Answer: BD
B--> routing table is from an Edge Router for sure.
D--> default and prefered route 0.0.0.0/0 is being learn by OMP protocol(m*)

Selected Answer: BD
B and D are correct

Selected Answer: BD
B/D for sure

Selected Answer: BD
Correct answer is B and D

Selected Answer: AD
ISR because is VRF and not VPN in the show
default route is learned from OMP because "m" in the show ip route is for OMP
B, D is Correct
Can anyone explain this? No clue why this should be A and B...

choices.C: The configured policy is adding a route tag of 300 to learned routes.
choices.A: The default route is configured locally.
choices.E: The routing table is for the transport VPN.
choices.D: The default route is learned via OMP.
choices.B: This routing table is from a cEdge router.

questions.question_text: When a WAN Edge device joins the Cisco SD-WAN overlay, which Cisco SD-WAN component orchestrates the connection between the WAN Edge device and a vSmart controller?

discussion.content:
B. vBond 
When a WAN Edge device joins the Cisco SD-WAN overlay, the vBond Orchestrator is responsible for orchestrating the connection between the WAN Edge device and a vSmart controller. It authenticates new devices and facilitates their connection to the vSmart Controller, eliminating the need for manual processes

Selected Answer: B
quit agree with mr Chiper

Correct.

Cisco vBond resides in the orchestration plane. The vBond controller is largely
responsible for the Zero-Touch Provisioning process as well as first-line
authentication, control/management information distribution, and facilitating
Network Address Translation (NAT) traversal.
Correct . Orchestration = vBond

choices.A: Create Applications or Groups of Interest > Configure Traffic Data > Apply Policies to Sites and VPNs.
choices.B: Configure VPN Membership > Apply Policies to Sites and VPNs.
choices.C: Create Applications or Groups of Interest > Configure Traffic Rules > Apply Policies to Sites and VPNs.
choices.D: Configure Topology > Apply Policies to Sites and VPNs.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct. Application Aware Routing is under Configure Traffic Rules in vManage.
Reference: SD-WAN CBT Nuggets video course (instructor Knox Hutchinson).

To configure centralized policies using Cisco vManage, use the steps identified in the procedures that follow this section.

Start the Policy Configuration Wizard
Configure Groups of Interest for Centralized Policy
Configure Topology and VPN Membership
Import Existing Topology
Create a VPN Membership Policy
Configure Traffic Rules
Match Parameters - Control Policy
Match Parameters - Data Policy
Action Parameters - Control Policy
Action Parameters - Data Policy
Apply Policies to Sites and VPNs
Activate a Centralized Policy
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge-20-x/policies-book/centralized-policy.html
Create Applications or Groups of Interest > Configure Traffic Rules > Apply Policies to Sites and VPNS.

questions.question_text: An engineer must configure a centralized policy on a site in which all HTTP traffic should use the Public Internet circuit if the loss on this circuit is below 10%, otherwise MPLS should be used. Which configuration wizard fulfills this requirement?
